Dear Bill Harley:
I've now read (l) your basically evasive response to my letter; (2) Richie Myers'
indictment— unintentional, of course!— of ETV in general, and Southern ETV spe¬
cifically, for its failure to serve its black constituencies; (3) Art Hungerford's
document on personnel practices which, among other defects, seems more concerned
with raising, a priori, the spectre of the potential side effects of any proposed
remedies, than with the totally devestating nature of the disease which these
might be proposed to cure*
Let me first direct myself (in reverse order), to each of these communications; and
then make a final attempt to lay it on the line in as simple and direct a manner as
possible, so that I can elicit a response equally as unequivocal— and one devoid
of the evasion and obfuscation which has characterised MSB's previous responses to
the twin problems of racial discrimination in educational broadcasting's program¬
ming and personnel practices*
